ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: It is clear that Prof. Gollin is passionate about his field, and luckily for students, also passionate about teaching. He went out of his way on so many occasions to mentor students and entertain questions. For a student with zero background in agriculture, this was extremely refreshing and helped the learning process greatly. As an economist, Prof. Gollin was able to impressively communicate concepts about agricultural economics to an audience with a mixed background and experiences in economics.Looking back on the course, a few suggestions for improvement:1. More economics in coursework would have been useful. Problem sets with economic exercises would have strengthened student understanding. In fact, these problem sets might have been more useful than the quantitative assignments, or could be integrated into the quantitative assignments.2. The quantitative assignments were useful, but, could have been sharpened in terms of purpose and scope

This class was excellent both in the subject matter which was interdisciplinary and useful for my understanding of the issues as well as taught by an excellent professor. The professor was clearly interested in engaging students on the topic and made time and effort include students' interests in and out of class.

In my mind, this course is really worthwhile. I hope it stays around even if Professor Gollin isn't here next year. I would hope that he would stay onboard. However, I do want to clarify that I think that he is wonderfully passionate and enthusiastic about the content; however, he can take on a seemingly slow pace that I think has the consequence of losing a lot of people's attention. I often multi-tasked during this course, and it wasn't until I had to study for the final that I realized how much I had learned. I think it would be helpful for there to be a mid-term and also a set of readings that will be covered and some that are additional. This would help people know how to spend their time as would a more directed and scheduled syllabus - we often didn't know what was coming in throughout the class.
I really appreciated that Doug was so accessible, and so engaged with us as students. He made an effort to get to know everyone, which made the class feel more like a discussion than like a lecture.
Prof. Gollin's enthusiasm really pushed students to learn.
Excellent Professor, highly relevant topics covered.
Professor Gollin is a great teacher. He is very good at stimulating discussions in class, and he successfully pulls interesting comments out of most of the students.
This class fundamentally challenged assumptions about the forces of agriculture. These ideas will help shape my work and decisions in the future.
Professor Gollin's enthusiasm and expertise + the breadth of the content covered.
The course topic and Professor Gollin's passion for it, as well as his accessibility and willingness to discuss student interests outside of the classroom setting.
The teacher is very knowledgeable and he takes his time to make sure that the students really get the material.

That eventhough most students in the class had not taken economics or had experienced agricultural systems before, the professor was able to make both agriculture, policies and economics easy to grasp and discuss about.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: It would help to have a bit more up-front structure around the assignments and topics, for planning purposes.
Shorter but higher number of problem sets.
A more organized syllabus, which clearly states what readings we should look at each day, would be helpful.
It would have been nice to have a problem set on some of the "graphing" concepts to give us an opportunity to play with those ideas and understand them.

The course was poorly organized, with readings often assigned the night before class.In addition, I felt there was not sufficient discussion of the key relevant economic models. I would have appreciated some economics-type problem sets.
The pace should be a little faster.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Both the instructor and the TA were very helpful. The professor responded to emails and was very available for office hour discussions. The TA help review sessions before assignments and exams.
See above.
Instructor: feedback was highly valuable. Very dedicated to students! Want to take more courses with this instructor!
I found Prof. Gollin and Jeff both to be helpful and available outside of class.
The professor was incredibly available and interested in working with students.
Professor Gollin was extremely available and helpful at all times. The TA was not very accessible and his grading was always very strange and his comments unnecessarily harsh.
Not applicable.

The professor was always available and willing to listen and talk about both questions and ideas. The quality of his answers and direction was very encouraging. I thoroughly enjoyed writing my two papers thanks to Prof. Gollin´s advice and insight. I hope he is able to return to the school to teach this class to more students.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Essential. This is one of few courses at F&ES that deals with international development and environmental challenges from an economic perspective in the developing world. The course fit exactly into my research and academic and professional interests.
As someone interested in conservation, this topic is very important for understanding the drivers of land use change.
Anwer on question 16

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I have an interest in agriculture based on my prior work experience.
I am extremely interested in the subject material and wanted to get an overview of economics in agriculture.
Same as above.
I thought agriculture was very important to understand.
A strong interest in the course topic and an enjoyment of economic-style analysis.
I am interested in sustainable large scale agriculture in developing countries.

When I was working I often interacted and conversed with farmers, learning through them about their economic decisions and the management of their farm. I wanted to go deeper into those trends I had observed, see how these impact the environment and how governments or other institutions shape the way the market moves as to alter the practices and decisions farmers take.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes, it was extremely interesting and I learned a lot about economics that I didn't know before.
Yes! Surpassed expectations!
Yes, definitely. I learned a lot on topics that are very relevant to what I want to do in the future.
Not quite, though it didn't fall too far short.
Yes it did.
Yes it did.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes.
Yes! I hope Professor Gollin will stay on as an advisor to students next year!
Yes.
Yes I did
Yes I did.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Great course, try to do the readings as you go because they're extremely interesting and will make class discussion much more meaningful. They're much too long to read at the end of the semester before the exam.
Be active in class. Take advantage of the opportunity to explore issues more in depth through the papers and in discussions with the professor.
Do as much of the readings as possible and be sure to develop a relationship with Professor Gollin, as he is an excellent teacher and a terrific guy.
Do the readings!
